label: Letter from Esau Jenkins to Gedney Howe of the Antipoverty Program.
description: Letter from Jenkins seeking a grant for start-up funds to create a day care on Johns Island including budget materials and a list of supporters

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
Progressive Club Sea Island Center
River Road
John's Island, South Carolina
Mrs. Gadney Howe
Chairwoman, AntiPoverty Program 
554 Huger Street 
Charleston, South Carolina
Dear Chairwoman and Committee:
January 12, 1965
As President of the above organization since 1948, and also President of the Citizens Committee of Charleston County since 1959. 
I am submitting this proposal. These organizations are chartered by the State Department of South Carolina, and the charters of each 
signed by the Secretary of the State of South Carolina, Mr. O. Frank Thornton. The charters read: that the said organizations 
hold or desire to hold property in common for religious, educational, social, fraternal, charitable, or other elemosynary purpose. The 
said corporation are non-profit. Charters are number 1145 and 1859.
I am a native of Johns Island, Charleston County and South Carolina. I have been having monthly meetings with people over the years, 
trying to obliterate ignorance, to promote health and social, educational and civic welfare, and to combat juvenile delinquency 
--to secure a more rich and abundant life for ourselves and for our posterity.
The people with whom I work are some of the poorest ones on God's earth, I believe. If I were to tell you all the conditions of some
of the homes that I have visited, I don't think you would bekieve that these conditions still exist in America at this day and time.
Because of these unbelievably poverty-stricken people of whom so few people in rich America know anything. I request that as many of you
as possible, if you please, come to Johns Island and let me take you all over the Sea Islands and over Charleston County, that you 
may get a view of what I am talking about. Please notify Spring Street in Charelston, or 766-9147 at the Progressive Club Center, 
River Road, Johns Island. Because of the conditions borrowed and begged for money to help build a center that our boys where they can 
play basketball, table tennis, and other games, or skate. We have also had workshops on Citizenship. We have had a few folk song
festivals, which were all well-attended by both races. We can't have these too often because of the lack of money.
Now our people are asking us to assist themin many areas in which we cannot give help unless we can get a grant from the other 
antipoverty Program. The following are the thinds these poor

page two:
people are requesting:
1. Day care for pre-school age childrenfrom seven A.M. to six P.M.
2. Classes in sewing, knitting and ceramics and other crafts for the 16 to 21 age group in the evening from seven to nine.
3. Evening classes in basketball, weightlifting, adult remedial reading, music, and workshops pm ,pra; amd citizenship resposibility, including 
taking part in registration and voting and learinin to use the voting machine.
4. The creation of some jobs for children who have left school, and after-school jobs for schoolchildren.
These requests have come from approximately thirty parents who make from $600.00 to $2,000.00 a yearand have from two to eight children 
in their homes. About fifty of these children are too young to go to school, causing the school-age children to stay out of school two
or three days a week to take care of the younger ones when the mothers and fathers are out working to support the children and the homes.
This condition causes many of our children to drop out of schools. Abscence from classes and poverty are the reasons. The children 
become too old and too large for the low grades, and younger children trase them about this and thy become asheamed and quit school.
If we will be considered for the grant asked for, we can employ tweleve or fourteen persons for the Progressive Club Center's programs, 
and one full-time secretary and two part-time workers at the Citizens Committee office, 41 Coming Cannon Street.
This may not contain all of the information you would like to have, but this is a basic description of what the poepl in our community 
are asking for at this time. I would like to ask for someone from your office to assist us in writing a final proposal if this 
does not meet the approval of the Governor and the Committee.
A grant of $107,640.00 for a two-year program, or $53,820.00 for one year, will help us set up a working staff of people whom we feek are 
capable of running this project well. We are enclosing a proposal on expenditures of these funds, and realize that we will have to recieve 
expert advice in making up a final proposal.
Madam Chariwoman and Gentlemen, if you would give us this badly needed grant, whihc would help alleviate povery in this area, 
we are willing to do our part in seeing this become a reality.
Our kitchen, plumbing and sleeping quarters at the Progressive Club Center have been inspected by the Board of Health  and approved.
At present we have enough bes to put 38 children in for their mid-day rest, and also a place large enough to feed them. These facts
are known by the Board of Health and approved. At present we have enough beds to put 38 children in for their mid-day rest, and also a 
place large enough to feed them, These facts are known by the many hundreds of people who have benefited from our services in one way or 
another. The above cost is what it will take for elven months' operation per yearly for two years. One month's vacation us taken each
year.

page four:
Cc: Governor of South Carolina, Columbia, S.C.
The following persons have signed the above proposal because of the crying need in thier organizations:
(signed) Esau Jenkins President, Progressive Club Citizens Committee
(signed) J.H. Washington Pastor, Zion [and] Hebron Churches
(signed) G.C. Brown Pastor, Wesley, St. James,
Webster, and Bethlhem churches
(signed) Guy Carawan Music Teacher and chairman of Folk Song Festivals
(signed) St. J. Heyward Mininster on Johns Island

Day Care 7:30 AM to 5;30 PM

Director $4, 140.00

$1,200.00 Day Care
$22,920.00
Recreatins and (Evening Classes for Youth and Adults

$6,200.00 Crafts Instructor - Mrs. Dorothy Williams  2 evenings per week

$1,200.00 Baksetball Coach Rev. Washington, Hermena Jenkins 2 evenings per week
$480.00 Citizenship Education reading and writing 1 evening per week Justin Deas and Robinson[?] free hours
600.00 ministers' Council with Adults and Youth 1 evening per wk. Rev. Brown and Heyward
33,000.00 Office Supplites and maintanance of equipments and Rental of More
2,000.00 office supplies 
1,500.00 maintenance of Equipment 
2,200.00 Rental of Facilities
$38,700.00 I do not knwo of Transportation as of now and no foods figures
1,800 gas and [M.S. illegible]

The following person hav said they would like to see a day care center for small children and some kind of training in the evenings, 
as well as after school jobs, set up on John's Island. These people have children in and out of schools. Also they want recreation some 
afternoons for them. Children who need day care
1. Mr. and Mrs. Viola Campbell Jenkins- - - - -
2. Mrs. Emma Jenkins - - - - - - - -- - - - - - 1
3. Mrs. Ethel Choice  - - - - - - - - - - - - - 3

If needed, Miss Elise Robinosn would od cooking and typing. Many others would come in to help if this grant were made.

Day Care Program for Pre-School Age Children

Rental of facilities- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - 2,200
Total: for one year:$53,820
for two years: $107,640
(If we cannot get the two-year grant, we would appreciate a one-year grant.)	   
1 person who will like to take lying Miss Cornelia Williams Wadmalaw 559-1413
